I respect Kasparov immensely, but this is a plea for the start of WW3. I have to object. Please, let's not do this. But maybe Kasparov is telling us that it has already started, so we should try to stop it before it spreads? If so, that is really grim.

We seem to be on a path to escalation into direct Ru vs. NATO military conflict, & insofar as we really are on that path, the nuclear risk is more than just slightly elevated & continues to grow for as long as we're on it. https://t.co/c8dpEsEqdZ

I hope this is all wrong, because if it's right then that's pretty grim and the main hope for the world now is that Putin is toppled by his own people and oligarchs.

From Putin's POV per the speech, Ukraine is a NATO puppet regime & NATO's plan is to encircle Russia & give it the Iraq treatment. So by attacking Kyiv, he's already attacking NATO. The Rubicon is already crossed. Russia & NATO are already at war.

I think about the thread also in the context of this Putin speech, which you should read. Everything in the thread tracks w/ this speech. Also, it's clear Putin thinks that by going into Ukraine he's /already/ directly at war w/ NATO.  https://t.co/Sgu9NqxZGt

That said, it is very possible that his thread is correct about the Russian POV, & that Russians are interpreting NATO reluctance to get directly, kinetically involved (no-fly, attacking convoys, etc.) as weakness that encourages them to push even harder. That would be maxium bad

Alternate take here from a Russian POV. I encourage you to read it. But I gotta point out that the fear expressed by myself, Judah, others, is not about "not getting hurt." It's about not getting nuked. Two different categories of things. https://t.co/NwcxJrIHkp

I thought about the many impossibly dumb ideas that I've seen gain purchase among the commentariat in the past 2yrs, & then I thought about how their impossibly dumb extreme opposites are then promoted by many of the same accounts -- a Hegelian dialectic of doom & imbecility.

As I watched various VSPs on my feed flip to "let's shoot at Russians b/c that'll definitely work out", I thought back to the way public health VSPs flipped from "going to the beach == genocide" to "going to a protest actually promotes public health & is your duty"...

I had a really low opinion of this particular tweet yesterday, & I expressed it on here, but by the time I had gotten into bed last night I had seen enough unbelievable objectively pro-WW3 tweets from Very Serious People that I was like "ah crap... oh man... God help us..." https://t.co/hHDTrXHgk0

The thing about a pair of vise grips is that you don‚Äôt always need them, but when you need them you REALLY need them. I have regular vise grips but I‚Äôve been eyeing these for the bug out bag for like 2 years. By the time I decided to do it, they were lost to supply chain probs.

This reminds me of the idiots who were big mad about the nail polish that can detect roofies in drinks, on the grounds that it might reinforce "rape culture." More like ü§° culture. https://t.co/haUH89k1eL

Seriously man, nothing cheeses me off like the idea that if we take resilience and civil defense seriously, that will automatically mean we are chill with nuclear war & therefore it'll be more likely. It's like saying if you buckle up you're more likely to get in a wreck. Morons.

RT @JoshuaPotash: The future is a very weird place. Ukrainians are uploading videos on TikTok about how to drive abandoned or captured Russ‚Ä¶
RT @DavidInglesTV: Global commodity prices from metals to energy to food are seeing gains of the sort we usually see on annual scales. And‚Ä¶

Ultimately, anything we've already done to them we've placed on the table as something they can do back as a proportional response (not an escalation). SWIFT has been hacked before. Could they shut it down? Could they freeze American or EU assets w/ cyber? Shut down our ATMs?

Of course, I don't want to oversell this because it's probably very unlikely. It would be EXTREMELY risky b/c we may be able to attribute it to them -- they may screw up the fake attribution to Ru -- & then we'd attack them.

A smaller, much weaker cyber adversary may reason that a nuclear exchange between Ru & NATO would be dangerous but not catastrophic for it, & would sort of level the global playing field (literally). So they could decide it's to their advantage to try & spark one.

Hoisting this from the thread b/c it's something I've been thinking about. As Ru & NATO escalate, an opportunity opens for smaller enemies to use cyber + fake attribution + fog of war to try & push both parties over the line into open war. https://t.co/m4JDM0ZuEX

Basically think of things that are disruptive & economically damaging, but short of an open attack on the grid, & that's what we could be in for as this escalates. Again, look at scenes of bank lines & domestic chaos in Ru, & expect them to try to replicate that here via cyber.

To upshot of all this, is that the US's largest logistics company going offline last week due to ransomware is probably a preview of what Ru cyberattacks will look if/when they start in earnest. We could have problems w/ banking, commerce, travel, telecom. https://t.co/Uu13XdpECL

This attribution issue is even more critical if the attack is wider. Say the power goes out in the whole Northeast & it's a regional catastrophe. This is an act of war & we really really really gotta be sure that DPRK isn't playing a game of "let's you & him fight" with us & Ru.

So imagine a cyberattack that cuts power to all of NYC. Is this an act of war? Like, do we risk nuclear escalation over this? Not only do we have to answer that, but we also have to ask: do we know the Russians really did this, & not, say, North Korea or Iran?

Complicating all this is the issue of attribution. It's often quite difficult to firmly attribute a particular attack to an attacker. For instance, there was a recent story about the wiper malware used by Ru having a Chinese language conditional in it. ü§î

I imagine there will be other attacks on commerce, & generally the idea will be to sow the kind of chaos over her that we've sown over there with our financial moves. We did it to them w/ SWIFT & asset freezes, so they will approximate that w/ cyberattacks.

Take the sanctions we're using against Ru. This is devastating but it's not turning off their grid. So they'll seek to respond proportionally, probably by attacking our banking & payments system. It's tit-for-tat, but they're using the tools they have (= cyber).

If Ru takes down our power grid, or we take down theirs, our response will be the same as if they had taken out our grid w/ bombs. Likewise if we take out theirs. So when you're trying to game out what might happen, you look at things that fall short of the line of full-on war.

On the calibration front, the attacker wants to cause maximum damage & chaos without tipping over into the line of destroying critical infra & killing a bunch of people, because that line is a clear casus belli & then we're in MAD territory. So for instance, taking down the grid.

I don't have a good explainer link, so seconding the request. That said, here's the way I've been thinking about this:

There are two issues with a cyberattack: calibration & attribution. (Maybe more but these are the 2 I think about. Happy to hear others.) https://t.co/8UlB5afGAa
An opposing view: https://t.co/0jiXpIVhHk

The #1 worry I have right now is I don‚Äôt know what Putin‚Äôs off ramp is. How does he save face except by escalating?
This classic from @paulg doubles as a doomsday prepper manifesto. Read it and then go get some runway. https://t.co/itUW6WZ0aP

Not dying until you get a lucky break is a real plan that works in the real world. I commend it to everyone in every seemingly hopeless situation. And if it doesn‚Äôt work for you, at least you went down fighting.

It‚Äôs not just anxiety reduction, tho it is that & that‚Äôs valuable. It‚Äôs runway, and the longer the odds the more runway I want. Unless you‚Äôre in the blast radius & moving doesn‚Äôt make sense, it‚Äôs never pointless or a cope to get more runway. Hard yes to runway.

I don‚Äôt need to predict the future or plan for all eventualities. What I need in the face of uncertainty & catastrophe are two things: time & options. Doomsday preps give me both. And doomsday preps are well beyond tornado preps.

Hard disagree here. As a founder & investor, I‚Äôm intimately familiar with the concept of runway. I know first-hand what it is to get like liftoff, & I know what it is to run out & crash. Doomsday preps are runway. The plan is to not die until something breaks your way. https://t.co/UkCAwgnT4g

This move shortens the launch window & gives us less time to decide if whatever signal we‚Äôre seeing is a Russian strike or just noise. This plus heightened tensions of war is a very dangerous moment. Take it seriously & make sober, careful plans.
